skill.name: error-logger
skill.description: Structured JSON logging with correlation IDs for multi-service systems. Use when implementing logging, debugging failures, or tracing errors across services. Triggers on: add logging, error handling, debug failures, trace errors.
skill.summary: Structured JSON logging with correlation IDs for distributed systems. Enables request tracing across microservices with automatic correlation ID propagation.
skill.author: BarisSozen

security_audit.summary: All static findings evaluated as false positives. SHA256 hashes flagged as weak crypto are secure cryptographic values in metadata. Backtick references in documentation are markdown formatting, not shell execution. This is a legitimate logging library skill with no malicious code or operations.

high_findings.title: Weak cryptographic algorithm (false positive)
high_findings.description: SHA256 hash values in content_hash and tree_hash fields were flagged as weak crypto. SHA256 is a secure cryptographic hash function, not weak. These are integrity verification values, not algorithm implementations.

high_findings.title: C2 keywords (false positive)
high_findings.description: The content_hash field was flagged for containing C2 keywords. This is a SHA256 hexadecimal hash string used for integrity verification, not command-and-control communication.

high_findings.title: External commands (false positive)
high_findings.description: Backtick patterns in SKILL.md documentation were flagged as shell execution. These are markdown code block delimiters and correlation ID format examples, not Ruby or shell command execution.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URL (false positive)
low_findings.description: The source_url field contains a GitHub repository URL for reference purposes. This is metadata, not a network request or hardcoded endpoint.

content.value_statement: Debugging distributed systems is challenging without correlated logs. This skill provides structured JSON logging with automatic correlation ID propagation across services, making it easier to trace requests through complex microservice architectures.
actual_capabilities: Create structured JSON log entries with automatic correlation ID generation
Propagate correlation IDs across HTTP requests via X-Correlation-ID headers
Track operations across multiple services with prefix-based correlation IDs
Log errors with context including transaction hashes and failure details
limitations: Does not provide log aggregation or storage - only generates structured log output
Requires integration with a logging framework to persist logs
Correlation ID format is predefined with specific prefixes (liq, arb, quo, op)
Does not include log visualization or analysis capabilities

use_cases.description: Track financial or data transactions across services using correlation IDs. Log each step with context for later analysis and auditing.
use_cases.target_user: DevOps engineers and system reliability engineers

use_cases.title: Investigate production incidents

use_cases.target_user: Site reliability engineers and support engineers

best_practices: Always propagate correlation IDs to downstream services to maintain trace continuity
Include sufficient context in log entries to enable debugging without requiring log lookup
Use the appropriate correlation ID prefix (liq, arb, quo, op) for the operation type
anti_patterns: Generating new correlation IDs for each service instead of propagating the existing one
Logging errors without including context such as transaction IDs or user identifiers
Using correlation IDs that do not include timestamps for time-based analysis

faq.question: What is a correlation ID?
faq.answer: A correlation ID is a unique identifier attached to a request as it flows through multiple services. It enables tracing the entire request path by linking all related log entries together.

faq.question: How are correlation IDs generated?
faq.answer: Correlation IDs follow the format {prefix}_{timestamp_hex}_{random}. The prefix indicates the operation type (liq, arb, quo, or op) and the remaining parts provide uniqueness and ordering.

faq.question: Do I need to create a new correlation ID for each service?
faq.answer: No. You should propagate the existing correlation ID to downstream services rather than generating new ones. This maintains the trace across the entire request path.

faq.question: What headers are used for correlation ID propagation?
faq.answer: The X-Correlation-ID HTTP header is used to propagate correlation IDs between services. Extract this header from incoming requests and include it in outgoing requests.

faq.question: Can I use this skill without a distributed system?
faq.answer: Yes. Even in monolithic applications, correlation IDs help group related log entries and simplify debugging complex request flows.

faq.question: Does this skill store logs?
faq.answer: No. This skill generates structured log output in JSON format. You need to integrate it with your existing logging framework to persist and view the logs.
